statement.tex: %text Write the direction-cosines of the line joining the points $(1,0,0)$ and $(0,1,1)$. %

step.context: %text What are the direction cosines of a line that makes an angle of $\alpha$ with the $x$-axis $\beta$ with the $y$-axis and $\gamma$ with the $z$-axis? %
step.reason: %text The definition of direction cosines of a line are the cosines of the angles the line makes with the $x$, $y$ and $z$ axes respectively. %

step.context: %text What are the direction cosines of the line joining $(1,0,0)$ and $(0,1,1)$? %
step.reason: %text If the distance between the points $(1,0,0)$ and $(0,1,1)$ is $d$, then % \begin{align} d &= \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2+(z_2-z_1)^2} \\ &=\sqrt{(0-1)^2+(1-0)^2+(1-0)^2} \\ &=\sqrt{1+1+1}=\sqrt{3} \end{align} \\ %text Therefore, the direction cosines are, % \begin{align} \cos \alpha&=\dfrac{x_2-x_1}{d}=\dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \cos \beta &=\dfrac{y_2-y_1}{d}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \cos \gamma &= \dfrac{z_2-z_1}{d}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \end{align}
